node.title: 'Organoids' could take the guesswork out of finding the most-effective neurological drugs
node.description: About a third of people with epilepsy never achieve effective seizure control, but University of Queensland researchersÂ hope they can soon end the trial and error of treatment and better predict the drug combinations for individual patients.
node.content:
["Queensland researchers have turned blood samples from epilepsy patients into functioning human brain tissue, allowing them to test the effectiveness of different combinations of anti-seizure drugs.", "University of Queensland (UQ) scientist Ernst Wolvetang hopes\u00a0the novel approach will take the guesswork out of prescribing seizure drugs to epilepsy patients, a process that is often a long journey of trial and error\u00a0for neurologists.", "About a third of people with epilepsy never achieve effective seizure control.", "Professor Wolvetang's team at UQ's Australian Institute for Bioengineering and Nanotechnology has created human brain tissue in a petri dish.", "It produces electrical activity and mimics\u00a0human brain waves.", "They isolate white blood cells from patients'\u00a0blood samples and reprogram them into stem cells that can be turned into any other cell type in the human body \u2014\u00a0including neurons.", "", "
The researchers\u00a0reprogram white blood cells\u00a0into stem cells that can be turned into neurons.(Supplied: University of Queensland)
", "Professor Wolvetang said\u00a0by adding growth factors at appropriate times, they can create functioning brain tissue, dubbed brain \"organoids\".", "The lentil-sized organoids have the same cellular make-up and architecture as specific regions of a developing human brain, such as the cerebral cortex \u2014 the outer layer, or grey matter,\u00a0used for thinking.", "Professor Wolvetang's team is working with the Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital and Melbourne's Monash University on the epilepsy research, funded by the Medical Research Future Fund.", "He said they use\u00a0artificial intelligence to make predictions for a patient's anti-seizure drugs based on their genetics, medication history, health records and other data.", "", "
University of Queensland scientist Ernst Wolvetang is researching the effectiveness of different combinations of anti-seizure drugs.(Supplied: University of Queensland)
", "Researchers then test the suggested drug combinations on the brain organoids.", "\"This will facilitate evidence-based drug selection,\" Professor Wolvetang said.", "\"There's a plethora of anti-seizure medications. That's not an issue. The problem is to find the right combination for the right person against the right type of epilepsy.", "\"Our approach, because it is personalised to the patient with the organoids \u2026 has the potential to fundamentally transform epilepsy care.\"", "", "
Professor Wolvetang and his team creating an organoid\u00a0in the lab.(Supplied: University of Queensland)
", "Mater Advanced Epilepsy Service director Dr Lisa Gillinder, who is not involved in the research, said advances in treatment options for patients living with epilepsy were desperately needed.", "\"Models of precision medicine have the potential to optimise the utilisation of current anti-seizure therapies,\" Dr Gillinder said.", "Griffith University neuropsychiatrist Professor Harry McConnell, who specialises in epilepsy, said Professor Wolvetang's research represents\u00a0a new and innovative approach to the treatment of seizures.", "\"It is still in the very early stages but, if successful, has a real potential to change the way we research treatments into epilepsy as well as other neurological conditions,\" he said.", "", "
Neurologist\u00a0Lisa Gillinder says treatment advances are urgently needed for epilepsy patients.(ABC News: Mark Leonardi)
", "Brain organoids are also being used to help UQ researchers study other neurological conditions, including Alzheimer's disease and the rare, incurable disorder Ataxia-Telangiectasia (A-T).", "They have found A-T is a disease of accelerated ageing.", "Professor Wolvetang said the studies paved the way for the possibility of developing new treatments for A-T.", "\"This is not just an academic exercise, this has real-life impacts,\" Professor Wolvetang said."]
